comment_1:
If you will actually read ANYTHING online instead of talking out of your ass you will realize what this song is truly about.

It is about his journey into Recovery (hints the Albums' name) and sobriety.  He struggled with drug addiction & has been able to overcome his disease.

At any rate, the lyrics are easy to understand to anyone in recovery as they are based on the 12 Step/AA/NA/etc views & slogans/sayings about recovery and our disease.

He is Not Afraid to take a stand and face his demons and the wreckage of his past.  For myself, I continued to use because of the guilt, shame and remorse of my actions the previous day(s), weeks, months and then years; so he is willing to face those things and recover from his addiction.  If you will read his Wikipedia page and the Wikipedia page for this song it will give you some insight into his addiction and ultimately his recovery from the progressive illness he and I are afflicted with.
comment_2: metaphors galore...  total eargasm.  love him or hate him, there is no denying that he's got talent!

comment_5: In the chorus I believe that Eminem is coming back full force out of a deep depression and a dark time in his life. He is saying that he's coming back without worries of regression. He's also saying that if anyone else has the problems he had he knows what they are going through and he will lift them up. Eminem is saying that no matter how hard life gets you will have people to lift you up along the way and people have been down the road before you and you are able to come back from it because others were able to.
comment_6:
I'm wondering if anybody really knows what this song is about.  Some of it is just small talk but the overall message is about recovery from addiction.  In a 12 step program, our main goal is to recover & help others recover from addiction. That's why he says "Everybody come take my hand, we'll walk this road together."  The whole "not afraid to take a stand"... in my opinion has to do with an addict's ego because when we let go of the drugs, one of the first things we have to deal with is our ego because we're always worried about what other people will think about us quitting drugs or what others will think about the fact that we even did drugs.  When he says, "thought I had it mapped out but I guess I didn't, this f-ing black cloud still follows me around but it's time to exercise these demons, these motherf-ers are doin' jumpin' jacks now!"  A lot of times, in recovery we try to do things our own way & we think we can.. and most of us never really understand why we are so addicted, or why even when we have stopped doing drugs or alcohol for a long period of time, we are still an addict and/or alcoholic (this f-ing black cloud still follows me around)... so we have to always work against the disease to keep it at bay (but it's time to exercise these demons). The line, "These motherf-ers are doin' jumpin' jacks now!".. if you haven't been in recovery, you would never know what he's talking about. Addiction/alcoholism is a progressive disease whether you're using or not and they say the whole time you're clean, your addiction is still getting stronger, doing jumping jacks in the back of your mind.
My favorite verse of the whole song is the last one, where he says, "Cause the way I feel, I'm strong enough to go to the club or the corner pub & lift the whole liquir counter up cause I'm raising the bar, I shoot for the moon but I'm too busy gazing at stars, I feel amazing & I'm not afraid..."  He is saying that he is strong enough in his recovery to put himself in a tempting situation without giving in. LOVE THIS SONG!!!!
comment_7: I love all the little puns that he puts in this song.  "Quit playing with scissors and shit, and cut the crap" is a good one.  It's so cool how he addresses all of his fans and even admits that his last album was sub-par.

 Everybody (Everybody)

this next line refers to what a lot of twelve step groups say about addiction while your in a meeting your addiction is in the parking lot doing jumping jacks or push-ups just waiting for you to slip up

comment_34:
Eminemâs poetic delivery in his song âNot Afraidâ is stunning! His explosive authenticity is what moves me to not just hearing the beats but listening to the words in the lyrics. There are metaphors that Eminem creatively uses are culturally relevant to his listeners. There is a clear cut and straight to the point that Eminem raps to not beat around the bush with admitting his responsibility in what he contributes to this world. Eminem realizes he plays a large part in life to his children, to his fans, and to this world. What Eminem knows is that at the lowest he could go, he was elevated back up by an impulse, a will, a release of fear, letting go of control, and remembering his capabilities, strengths and talents that are within him leading him to what he desires to become. 

We can all ask ourselves who are we becoming by looking at where we are at in life. I think Eminem is inspirational and courageous and I appreciate his contributions to this world. 

One last observation I had comes from my belief in God. I know God loves Enimem and has created his with a purpose and destiny. No matter who we are or what we are going through, God is with us and loves us non-stop. Nothing can separate us from Godâs love and who he has created us to be, which is inspirational, creative and motivated individuals. I thank God for Eminem and the freedom we all have in Jesus Christ who took all our baggage to the cross and calms the storms in our lives!

comment_61:
By looking at Eminem's recent albums, we can obviously tell what he's talking about. In the one song, he mentions how he had problems with opiates, namely vicodin, valium and methadone.

Getting clean is the most amazing feeling I have ever experienced, I can directly relate to the lines:
"Cause the way I feel, I'm strong enough to go to the club
 Or a corner pub and lift the whole liquor counter up
 Cause I'm raising the bar"

The whole song is talking about the ups and downs of addiction. "Holla if you've been down the same road."

comment_73: I enjoy reading everyones interpretations and I believe this song does have a lot to do with overcoming addiction. I also think its his way of no longer allowing anyone or anything to have control over his life, his feelings or his decisions. He is standing his ground, he is no longer afraid. He doesn't care what anyone thinks and is going to follow his heart regardless of what anyone has to say about it. I think it is also his way of reaching out to people to let them know they are not alone in their struggles. I think it is  a message to stand up and fight when it seems the odds are against you. Instead of giving up when all seems lost, TAKE back the life that is yours and regain control.....I personally have demons I am fighting right now, and this song gets played on the daily. It is an inspiration to me, reminds me of how incredibly strong I am even when I feel defeated, and it is one of many songs that keeps me going. I also think that lyricists write their music a certain way, knowing that every listener will have a different perception of its meaning. I think that is something that makes music so incredible. One person can get something entirely different than someone else, its universal in a way.
